nodes.body:
Expressive particles are common in both Standard and Literary Tibetan. Some go at the beginning of a sentence and some at the end, after the verb.

Of those that go at the beginning, the most common are:

  • ཨོ་ “Oh!”
  • ཨ་ལའི་ “Well, well....”
  • ཨ་ཙི་ “Rats!” “Darn!” “Bugger!”
  • ཨ་རོ་ “Ow!”
  • ཨ་ཆུ་ “Oh, that’s cold!”
  • ཨ་ཚ་ “Ouch, that’s hot!”
  • ཨ་ཁ་ “What a shame!”
  • ཨ་མ་ “Oh Lordy!” (Literally: “O mother!”)

The particles that appear most frequently at the end of a sentence are:

  • ད་
  • པ་ (and its variants ག་, ང་)

ད་ often implies that the speaker is not in agreement with the person to whom he’s speaking, or is emphasizing the surprising or threatening nature of the situation in question.

  • འདི་དཔེ་རང་རེད་ད། “It’s pretty amazing, huh?”
  • རྐུ་མ་ཤོར་གྱི་རེད་ད། “But you’ll be robbed!”
  • ཉེན་ཁ་ཡོད་རེད་ད། “But there is some danger!”
  • རྟ་ཤོར་སོང་ད། “Watch out, the horse has escaped!”

པ་ and its variants ག་ and ང་ are subject to the same modifications as the interrogative particles པས་, གས་, and ངས་ (xxlink 2.3.1). Using these implies that that speaker is trying to elicit agreement with what he is saying, and correspond to tag questions. They may therefore be translated in English by “Isn’t that so?” or “Don’t you think?” English might also convey these by intonation.

  • ཁྱེད་རང་གི་སྤུ་གུ་ཆེན་པོ་ཆགས་འདུག་ག “My God, how your child has grown!”
  • ད་ལྟ་ཕྱི་པོ་རེད་པ། “It’s late now, isn’t it?”
  • སྐྱིད་པོ་བྱུང་སོང་ང་། “It was very pleasant! Eh?”
  • ངས་ཁྱེད་རང་ལ་ཞུས་བྱུང་ང་། “I told you, didn’t I?”
  • ཁྱེད་རང་སློབ་སྦྱོང་ཧུར་བརྩོན་ཞེ་དྲགས་བྱེད་ཀྱི་འདུག་ག “You study really hard, don’t you?”
